text: this is baby Majid he's two days old his
mother Amon had to be rushed to hospital
through a snowstorm to give birth now
they're having to live with neighbors in
the next shack because there's got
flooded water came through and
everything got soaked she says we had to
borrow blankets and everything from the
neighbors
her husband zakariya showed me the shack
they had to abandon when it flooded he
said they had to borrow a hundred pounds
or so to pay the hospital for the birth
I have a few says no money no bread no
sugar no wood for the fire mohnish this
is the world that baby Majid was born
into it's one of hundreds of squatter
settlements scattered throughout Lebanon
it doesn't allow the construction of
formal camps the people here have
received no help at all apart from some
wood to make the frames for their shacks
and some plastic sheeting to keep the
rain out
many of them have stoves inside but
finding fuel is the real problem
there's no sanitation just makeshift
outside toilets Lebanon has already
taken in over 1 million Syrian refugees
and yet they keep coming despite the
appalling conditions that they face here
people here living in squatter camps
like this really have no other option
and if they had the chance to go to
Europe many simply wouldn't take it
Mohamed fled here a year ago with his
family from northeast Syria despite the
harsh conditions he doesn't want to go
anywhere except home I asked him if he'd
go to Europe if he had the chance no I
wouldn't go this is Lebanon we feel at
home with the Lebanese of course we want
more help and if there's peace we would
want to go home but on the other side of
the mountains which form the border with
Syria the war rages on with little hope
of a settlement so hundreds of thousands
of refugees are destined to remain in
these squalid conditions unless
something changes this is where baby
Majid will be spending his childhood
